courseTitle: Introduction to Histology: Skin Virtual Lab

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will learn about the function, structure, and anatomy of skin, including the <button className='glossary-text'>epidermis</button >, <button className='glossary-text'>dermis</button >, and <button className='glossary-text'>hypodermis</button> layers. Then, you will examine a slide of human skin using a virtual microscope.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Activity 1: Microscope Tutorial – 15 minutes 
Activity 2: Observing Different Tissue Types – 60 minutes
pageData.desc:
Activity 1: Microscope Tutorial – 15 minutes, 
Activity 2: Observing Different Tissue Types – 60 minutes

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify the different layers of the skin and describe their general functions.
Identify and describe the different tissue types making up the , the , and subcutaneous layer.
Compare and contrast thick and thin skin in terms of structure and anatomical location.
Differentiate among the layers of the epidermis based on cell viability and keratinization.

pageData.text: 17th century Italian biologist and physician, Marcello Malpighi, is referred to as the founder of microscopical anatomy and histology. Malpighi used microscopes to first study the respiratory mechanisms of insects. He then studied frogs, sheep, and other mammals, including humans; he noticed capillary structures and described a complex network of how blood and oxygen moved through the body. This network is now referred to as a closed circulatory system, rather than an open circulatory system in which blood comes from the liver or spleen and pools in open spaces in the body.

Although the exact mechanism is not fully understood, researchers have recently identified that lung macrophages originate in the liver (the cells of which are shown here). Macrophages are an important component of the immune system, especially in the lungs where they fight viruses, bacteria, and fungi that are inhaled. Lung macrophages start from precursor cells in a fetus' liver. Once an infant takes its first breath, these cells migrate to the lungs and are stimulated to become macrophages. Later in life, these macrophages become monocytes and are also found in the blood<sup class='bodySupscript'>1</sup>.

1Evren, E., Ringqvist, E., Doisne, J., Thaller, A., Sleiers, N., Flavell, R.A., Di Santo, J.P., & Willinger, T. (2022). CD116 fetal precursors migrate to the perinatal lung and give rise to human alveolar macrophages. Journal of Experimental Medicine. 219 (2) DOI: 10.1084/jem.20210987

pageData.desc: A micrograph cross section of liver tissue.
pageData.altText: A micrograph cross section of liver tissue.

pageData.text: The body is covered by skin, which provides protection from abrasion, potentially infectious microbes, and fluid loss. There are two layers of skin: the superficial , composed of epithelial tissue, and the deeper , composed of connective tissue. Deep to the dermis lies another connective tissue layer, the , also called the subcutaneous layer. The hypodermis is not part of the skin proper, but it is closely associated with the skin and is vital for supporting its structure and functions. An overview of the skin is shown in .

The epidermis, as seen in Figure 1, is made up of <button className='glossary-text'>stratified squamous epithelium</button>. The main characteristics of this epithelial tissue are flattened cells, also called squamous cells, that are stacked in a layered pattern. The deepest layer of epithelial cells is separated from the underlying dermis by a <button className='glossary-text'>basement membrane</button>. The basement membrane is a specialized extracellular matrix, and its main function in the skin is to anchor the epithelial layer (epidermis) to the layer of connective tissue (dermis) directly underneath.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A cross-section of the epidermis, labeled

pageData.text: The most abundant cells of the <button className='glossary-text'>epidermis</button> are the specialized epithelial cells known as <button className='glossary-text'>keratinocytes</button>. These cells are produced in the deepest region of the epidermis, and they undergo maturation as they are pushed toward the skin surface. Part of the maturation process is the production of a fibrous protein called <button className='glossary-text'>keratin</button>, which helps to make the epidermis tough and water-resistant. As keratinocytes mature, they become composed of more and more keratin protein. Their cytoplasm becomes dominated by keratin instead of functional organelles. Eventually, by the time they reach the outermost area of the epidermis, the keratinocytes have died. They are sloughed off from the surface of the epidermis, which is why replacements are continuously generated.

In thick skin, such as that on the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands, there are five layers of epidermal cells (see Figure 2). Other parts of the body that have thin skin have only four distinct layers of epidermis.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A cross-section showing the five layers of epidermal cells in thick skin

text: The most superficial layer is the <button className='glossary-text'>stratum corneum</button>. Cells in this layer contain a high concentration of <button className='glossary-text'>keratin</button>, making this layer tougher than the rest. Dead cells are shed from the surface of this layer.

The layer just deep to the stratum corneum is the <button className='glossary-text'>stratum lucidum</button>. This clear layer of cells is only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet or the palms of the hands. Cells in this layer are very densely packed and contain hardly any organelles.
The next layer is the <button className='glossary-text'>stratum granulosum</button>, which is characterized by cells with a granular appearance due to cytoplasmic granules.
The <button className='glossary-text'>stratum spinosum</button> contains cells that appear small and spiny in traditionally prepared slides due to shrinking of the cells.

The deepest layer is the <button className='glossary-text'>stratum basale</button>. This layer contains <button className='glossary-text'>basal cells</button>, which are a type of stem cell. This is the layer that constantly produces new epidermal cells by mitosis.

pageData.question: Dead cells are shed from which skin layer?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Dead cells are shed from the surface of stratum corneum, the most superficial layer.

pageData.question: At which location would you expect to find five layers of skin instead of four?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In thick skin, such as that on the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands, there are five layers of epidermal cells.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In thick skin, there are five layers of epidermal cells. Other parts of the body with thin skin have only four distinct layers of the epidermis. The most superficial layer is the stratum corneum. Cells in this layer contain a high concentration of keratin, making this layer tougher than the rest. The layer just deep to the stratum corneum is the stratum lucidum. This clear layer of cells is only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet or the palms of the hands. Cells in this layer are very densely packed and contain hardly any organelles. The next layers down are the stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum, named for the distinctive appearance of their respective cells, and the stratum basale which contains a type of stem cell responsible for producing new epidermal cells by mitosis.

img.alt: Figure 2: A cross-section showing the five layers of epidermal cells in thick skin

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In thick skin, there are five layers of epidermal cells. Other parts of the body with thin skin have only four distinct layers of the epidermis. The most superficial layer is the stratum corneum. Cells in this layer contain a high concentration of keratin, making this layer tougher than the rest. The layer just deep to the stratum corneum is the stratum lucidum. This clear layer of cells is only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet or the palms of the hands. Cells in this layer are very densely packed and contain hardly any organelles. The next layers down are the stratum granulosum and stratum spinosum, named for the distinctive appearance of their respective cells, and the stratum basale which contains a type of stem cell responsible for producing new epidermal cells by mitosis.

img.alt: Figure 2: A cross-section showing the five layers of epidermal cells in thick skin

pageData.subTitle: Layers of the Dermis
pageData.text: The (see Figure 4) is made up of two distinct layers. The more superficial layer is the , which consists of areolar connective tissue. This region is characterized by fingerlike projections called , which create folds in the . This layer contains blood capillaries and sensory structures (see Figure 3).

pageData.desc: A diagram of the layers of the skin, labeled
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A diagram of the layers of the skin, labeled

pageData.desc: A cross-section showing the two distinct layers of the dermis
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A cross-section showing the two distinct layers of the dermis

pageData.text: The deeper layer of the is the . This layer is generally thicker than the papillary layer and gives the dermis strength and elasticity. This layer consists mainly of and is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers. The latter gave rise to the name reticular dermis. The overall alignment of collagenous fibers provides the skin with extra strength in a given direction. The hair and nail roots are based within this layer of the dermis and are surrounded by blood vessels. Specialized glands are also located in the reticular dermis.

<button className='glossary-text'>Sweat glands</button> (see Figure 5), also called sudoriferous glands, assist with temperature regulation. There are two types: <button className='glossary-text'>apocrine</button> sweat glands and <button className='glossary-text'>merocrine</button> (or eccrine) sweat glands. The apocrine sweat glands secrete their product directly into the hair follicles, especially in the armpits and groin. The merocrine sweat glands secrete sweat through pores directly onto the surface of the skin. They are much more numerous than apocrine sweat glands and serve a greater role in cooling the body (see Figure 6).

<button className='glossary-text'>Sebaceous glands</button> (oil glands) help keep the skin and hair flexible and water-resistant by secreting a substance called <button className='glossary-text'>sebum</button>. These glands are found throughout the skin except on the palms and soles. Some, but not all, sebaceous glands are closely associated with hair follicles. Sebum also protects the body with its bactericidal properties.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A section of skin displaying the apocrine and merocrine sweat glands
Figure 6: A diagram displaying the merocrine and apocrine sweat glands and the sebaceous gland in the epidermis and dermis

pageData.question: The dermis is mostly comprised of what type of tissue?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The dermis is mostly made up of different types of connective tissue, namely areolar and dense irregular connective tissues.

pageData.question: Which specialized glands are in the reticular dermis?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Sweat glands, also called sudoriferous glands, assist with temperature regulation and are found in the reticular dermis.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The dermis is made up of two distinct layers. The more superficial layer is the papillary dermis, which consists of areolar connective tissue. The deeper layer of the dermis is the reticular dermis. This layer is generally thicker than the papillary layer and gives the dermis strength and elasticity. This layer consists mainly of dense irregular connective tissue and is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers. The overall alignment of collagenous fibers provides the skin with extra strength in each direction. The hair and nail roots are based within this layer of the dermis and are surrounded by blood vessels. Specialized glands are also located in the reticular dermis that aid in temperature regulation.

img.alt: Figure 4: A cross-section showing the two distinct layers of the dermis

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The dermis is made up of two distinct layers. The more superficial layer is the papillary dermis, which consists of areolar connective tissue. The deeper layer of the dermis is the reticular dermis. This layer is generally thicker than the papillary layer and gives the dermis strength and elasticity. This layer consists mainly of dense irregular connective tissue and is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers. The overall alignment of collagenous fibers provides the skin with extra strength in each direction. The hair and nail roots are based within this layer of the dermis and are surrounded by blood vessels. Specialized glands are also located in the reticular dermis that aid in temperature regulation.

img.alt: Figure 4: A cross-section showing the two distinct layers of the dermiss

pageData.subTitle: Hypodermis
pageData.text: Deep to the is the , which connects the skin to the rest of the body. This layer is mainly made up of the loose connective areolar and . The areolar tissue contains widely spaced collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers arranged in all directions. It also contains a variety of cell types, all surrounded by abundant . Blood vessels and nerves are found throughout the hypodermis. The adipose tissue provides padding and thermal conservation for the body.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: A diagram of the layers of the skin, including glands, nerves, a hair follicle and bulb, veins, and arteries

pageData.question: Which of the following are found throughout the hypodermis?

options.text: blood vessels, nerves, and adipose tissue
blood vessels, basal cells, and oil glands

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Blood vessels, nerves, and adipose tissue are found throughout the hypodermis.

pageData.question: What is the function of adipose tissue in the hypodermis?

options.text: allows the body to conserve heat
helps keep the skin and hair flexible
insulates the epidermis from the dermis
transmits sensory information to the brain

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The adipose tissue provides padding and thermal conservation for the body.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Deep to the dermis is the hypodermis, which connects the skin to the rest of the body and is not considered a proper layer of the skin. This layer is mainly made up of the loose connective areolar and adipose tissues, and features blood vessels and nerves throughout. The areolar tissue contains widely spaced collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers arranged in all directions. The adipose tissue provides padding and insulation for the body.

img.alt: Figure 7: A diagram of the layers of the skin, including glands, nerves, a hair follicle and bulb, veins, and arteries

hintData.title: Hint

This layer is mainly made up of the loose connective areolar and adipose tissues, and features blood vessels and nerves throughout. The areolar tissue contains widely spaced collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers arranged in all directions. The adipose tissue provides padding and insulation for the body.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the skin proper?
In which layer of the epidermis would you expect to find the most immature keratinocytes?
Which layer of the epidermis is only found in thick skin, such as that found on the soles of the feet?
Hair and nail roots are based in which layer of the skin?
Which of the following best describes merocrine sweat glands?

options.text: They are primarily responsible for cooling the body.
They are like apocrine sweat glands but fewer in number.
They produce sweat directly into the hair follicles.
They are rooted in the epidermis.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following would you NOT expect to find in the hypodermis?
Which of the following is a property of the sebum secreted by oil glands in the skin?

pageData.title: Questions
text: If you were to observe a skin sample from the hand of someone who regularly performs manual labor, what would you see when looking at a section of the dermis?
A callus is a hardening of skin. Which protein is very abundant in a callus?
What will happen if the sebaceous glands slow their function?
Why does hair look shinier when we are sweating a lot?
Skin grows from a particular layer, what is the name of this layer and what might happen if this layer gets damaged?

data.title: Adipose tissue
data.content: A specialized form of connective tissue that stores fat in adipocytes

data.title: Apocrine
data.content: One of two types of sweat glands; they secrete their product directly into the hair follicles, especially in the armpits and groin

data.title: Basal cell
data.content: A type of stem cell found in the stratum basale

data.title: Basement membrane
data.content: A thin membranous layer of connective tissue that separates one layer of epithelial cells from the next

data.title: Dense irregular connective tissue
data.content: A type of connective tissue found in the dermis; it is especially rich in collagenous, elastic, and reticular fibers

data.title: Dermis
data.content: The layer of living tissue below the epidermis

data.title: Epidermis
data.content: The surface tissue layer of the skin

data.title: Ground substance
data.content: A component of ECM made up of mostly water with added polysaccharide and protein molecules for stability

data.title: Hypodermis
data.content: The connective tissue layer deep to the dermis; although not part of the skin proper, it is closely associated with the skin and is vital for supporting its structure and function; also called the subcutaneous layer

data.title: Keratin
data.content: A fibrous protein that helps to make the epidermis tough and water-resistant

data.title: Keratinocytes
data.content: The most abundant cells of the epidermis; they are specialized epithelial cells produced in the deepest region of the epidermis, and which undergo maturation as they are pushed toward the skin surface

data.title: Merocrine
data.content: One of two types of sweat glands that secrete sweat through pores directly onto the surface of the skin; also called eccrine

data.title: Papillae
data.content: Fingerlike projections in the papillary dermis that increase the strength of the connection between the epidermis and dermis

data.title: Papillary dermis
data.content: The more superficial of the two layers of the dermis; it consists of areolar connective tissue

data.title: Reticular dermis
data.content: The deeper of the two layers of the dermis; it is generally thicker than the papillary dermis, and gives the dermis strength and elasticity

data.title: Sebaceous glands
data.content: Oil glands that help keep the skin and hair flexible and water-resistant

data.title: Sebum
data.content: The water-resistant substance secreted by sebaceous glands; it also has bactericidal properties

data.title: Stratified squamous epithelium
data.content: A type of epithelial tissue made up of several layers of cells that are roughly cuboidal at the base of the epithelium, but go on to become progressively more flattened as they form the surface of the tissue; it makes up the epidermis

data.title: Stratum basale
data.content: The deepest layer of the epidermis

data.title: Stratum corneum
data.content: The most superficial layer of the epidermis

data.title: Stratum granulosum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum lucidum and which is made up of cells with a granular appearance due to cytoplasmic granules

data.title: Stratum lucidum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum corneum, and which is a clear layer of cells only present in the thick skin of the soles of the feet and the palms of the hands

data.title: Stratum spinosum
data.content: The layer of the epidermis deep to the stratum granulosum, and which contains cells that appear small and spiny in traditionally prepared slides due to shrinking of the cells

data.title: Sweat glands
data.content: Glands in the skin that assist with temperature regulation via product secretion; also called sudoriferous glands
